choices.text:
### System:
You are an AI assistant that follows instruction extremely well. Help as much as you can.

### User:
Explain origin of standard gauge for railways

### Response:


The invention of the standard-gauge railway system is often credited to Sir George MacDonald, a Scottish author known best known for his fairy tales. The idea behind this was that it would be more economical to run on rails closer together than widely separated ones. This allowed for trains sharing one set of tracks. Standard gauge rail transportation methods allow for cost savings in freight shipping.

Standard-gauge railway systems have become the norm, allowing multiple train lines while still maintaining a shared economy among them. The standard gauge system has proven itself as an efficient method to move large quantities of cargo across long distances at a reduced cost per unit shipped.—Ed.
